data.text: You shouldn't need a visa for any European countries, but you are not permitted to stay in the collective Schengen countries for more than 90 days total in any 180 day period. Balance it by planning a route in and out of the Schengen zone and using a Schengen Calculator to make sure you're not going to be in danger of overstaying. I traveled in Europe for 7 months using that strategy.

data.text: depends how long you plan to be in Europe. You can be in any Schengen country for a combined 90 days in a 180 day period with no visa as US is part of the visa waiver scheme. If wanting more than 3 months then you either need to aim for a non-schengen country, say Croatia for example, where you can enter for 3 months. So that gives you 6 months if you want. Another strategy if looking for more than 3 months in the Schengen area is to apply for a long term visa at one country, France for example which is relatively easy to get. You could then do 3 months in any schengen country, 3 months ( or up to 12 months) in France and the another 3 months in the schengen zone. Before you have to leave the schengen zone. That‚Äôs your options.

data.text:
In reality it is unlikely you will be detected unless you have some reason to be interacting with the authorities. (traffic fine, accident etc) but if you are detected I believe the current is immediate deportation and 5 year ban from re-entering. I have also heard of fines but can't confirm. However, be aware the EU is introducing an electronic border control system later this year. (ETIAS. Actually was introduced 1 Jan this year but will have a 12 month transition period) Similar to the US ESTA system. The thinking is that you a far more likely to be caught out once this is in place. https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/etias/
ETIAS - European Travel Information and Authorisation System
